title: Classic Sitcom Catchphrases
description: Can you match these iconic TV catchphrases to the right show or character?

questions.question: Which character said 'D'oh!' on a famous animated sitcom?
questions.explanation: Homer Simpson's 'D'oh!' became so iconic it was added to the Oxford English Dictionary in 2001.

questions.question: 'Lucy, you got some 'splainin' to do!' is associated with which show?
questions.explanation: Though Ricky never said these exact words on I Love Lucy, the phrase became synonymous with Desi Arnaz's character scolding Lucy.

questions.question: On which show would you hear 'Dy-no-mite!'?
questions.explanation: Jimmie Walker's character J.J. Evans made 'Dy-no-mite!' his signature catchphrase on Good Times (1974-1979).

questions.question: Who said 'How you doin'?' as a pickup line on Friends?
questions.explanation: Joey Tribbiani (Matt LeBlanc) used 'How you doin'?' as his signature flirtatious greeting throughout the series.

questions.question: 'One of these days, Alice... pow, right to the moon!' was Ralph Kramden's line on which show?
questions.explanation: Jackie Gleason as Ralph Kramden used this exaggerated threat (never carried out!) on The Honeymooners (1955-1956).

questions.question: Which sitcom character famously said 'Nanu Nanu'?
questions.explanation: Robin Williams as Mork from Ork used 'Nanu Nanu' as an Orkan greeting on Mork & Mindy (1978-1982).

questions.question: 'Bazinga!' is the catchphrase of which character?
questions.explanation: Sheldon Cooper (Jim Parsons) used 'Bazinga!' on The Big Bang Theory to indicate he'd made a joke.

questions.question: On Seinfeld, what was the catchphrase of the Soup Nazi?
options: 'Not that there's anything wrong with that'
questions.explanation: The Soup Nazi's 'No soup for you!' from the 1995 episode became one of Seinfeld's most quoted lines.

questions.question: Which character said 'Did I do that?' after causing destruction?
questions.explanation: Jaleel White as Steve Urkel made 'Did I do that?' his trademark on Family Matters (1989-1998).

questions.question: 'Yada, yada, yada' became a way of skipping details on which show?
questions.explanation: Seinfeld popularized 'Yada, yada, yada' in a 1997 episode where characters used it to gloss over important details.

questions.question: 'Whatchoo talkin' 'bout, Willis?' was said on which show?
questions.explanation: Gary Coleman as Arnold Jackson made this his signature line on Diff'rent Strokes (1978-1986).

questions.question: Which show featured the greeting 'Norm!' every time a character walked into a bar?
questions.explanation: On Cheers (1982-1993), the entire bar would shout 'Norm!' whenever George Wendt's character Norm Peterson walked in.

questions.question: 'Marcia, Marcia, Marcia!' expressed jealousy on which family sitcom?
questions.explanation: Jan Brady's jealous outburst about her older sister became one of The Brady Bunch's most memorable moments.

questions.question: Who would say 'Live long and prosper' with a Vulcan salute?
questions.explanation: Leonard Nimoy as Spock made the Vulcan salute and greeting 'Live long and prosper' iconic on Star Trek.

questions.question: 'Here's Johnny!' was Ed McMahon's nightly introduction for whom?
questions.explanation: Ed McMahon's booming 'Here's Johnny!' introduced Johnny Carson on The Tonight Show for 30 years (1962-1992).

questions.question: Which Taxi character said 'What does a yellow light mean?' over and over?
questions.explanation: Christopher Lloyd's Reverend Jim asked this repeatedly during his hilarious driving test scene on Taxi.

questions.question: 'Baby, you're the greatest!' was a kinder catchphrase from which TV husband?
questions.explanation: Jackie Gleason's Ralph Kramden would tell Alice 'Baby, you're the greatest!' on The Honeymooners, balancing his bluster.

questions.question: 'Sit on it!' was a dismissive catchphrase on which 1970s show?
questions.explanation: Fonzie (Henry Winkler) popularized 'Sit on it!' as a dismissive putdown on Happy Days (1974-1984).

questions.question: 'You big dummy!' was Fred Sanford's insult to his son on which show?
questions.explanation: Redd Foxx as Fred Sanford regularly called his son Lamont 'You big dummy!' on Sanford and Son (1972-1977).

questions.question: Which character's catchphrase was 'Ayyy!' accompanied by a thumbs up?
questions.explanation: Arthur 'Fonzie' Fonzarelli's cool 'Ayyy!' with a thumbs up became one of TV's most imitated gestures on Happy Days.
